content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a under-the-radar tower-defense game that is both fun and challenging. It's basic yet complex appearance may overwhelm those new to the genre, but Knuckle Cracker did a good job on slowly pacing the user into the concepts around Creeper World 3. The graphics of Creeper World 3 aren't anything extraordinary but they are pretty solid. The terrain is in a variety of colors and the illusion of layers is clearly there. The various tools and weapons stand out from the terrain and are simple to realize through the variation in shape and color. While everything looks basic throughout the game, the graphics are crisp and clear - and that's good enough for a tower defense game. The core gameplay of Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is one that is new to me. While I have played other games in the same sort of genre, Creeper World 3 is unique in the sense that it's attempting to fuse both Tower Defense and Strategy-Simulation. While the majority of tower defense's have you place your weapons on a certain path as enemies start to come at you on a predictable path - Creeper World 3 is adds a refreshing twist. Your enemy is the creeper. The creeper spreads outward in all directions, covering the terrain and destroying everything in it's path. It is your job to use the weapons at your disposal to take out the source of the creeper - being the emmiters. While it may not sound that hard, which it really isn't at first; the difficulty begins to ramp up. It will be very challenging for newcomers - including me at times, but I never really felt that the game was cheating. I also realized what mistakes I made if I were to fail. Throughout the game, you will play a variety of maps with the inclusion of the story. The story arc is the weakest point about this game, it's very forgettable and did nothing to increase the immersion or gameplay. It's a good effort nonetheless. The mouse controls are also great - with the ability to pause the game, plan you moves and move your units around where you please. Overall, the core mechanics of Creeper World 3 is great and will be something for all games in the similar genre to beat. The audio is good for a game like this. In all honestly, what can you expect. The music is fine with the occasion of it being repetitive. I found myself turning off the music at various times. The sound effects are pretty simple. Nothing special here.Creeper World 3's greatest strength is it's value. Like Skyrim, Portal 2 and Torchlight 2 before them, the sheer amount of user content is mind-blowing. At a cheap price of $15, it's pretty hard to not pick this one up if you are a fan of the genre. There are an abundance of maps, both pre-made and user-made all varying in difficulty. It's also good to note that some maps have been known as unbeatable. A random map generator is also here as well as an in-game editor to create your own maps for others to try. Creeper World 3 also has over 130 achievements for those who are into them. In conclusion, Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal was one of the more surprising buys for me. I didn't think I would enjoy the game this much. It is something I will continue to play for years to come. GRAPHICS: 8.0/10GAMEPLAY: 9.5/10STORY: 5.0/10AUDIO: 7.0/10CONTROLS: 9.0/10VALUE: 10/10OVERALL: 8.1/10+Refereshing take on genre+Challenging yet Fun+Solid Controls+Addictive+Great Variety in Maps and Units+Overwhelming amount of content +130+ Achievements+Inexpensive+/- Some Unbeatable Maps-Weak Story-Repetitive Music-Can sometimes be a grind

Posted: May 8, 2014
												I've been very interested in the Creeper World trilogy for as long as I can possibly remember. I first found a flash game affixed on the engine used in Creeper World 1, Creeper World Training Simulation[www.kongregate.com] on Kongregate, and ever since then I had been searching vigeriously for more Creeper World flash games. Next up was another game created by the engine used for Creeper World 1, Creeper World: Evermore[www.kongregate.com]. Following up on that, I also discovered Creeper World: User Space[www.kongregate.com]. Shortly after, I finally found a flash game affixed to the engine Creeper World 2 was made from, Creeper World 2: Academy[www.kongregate.com]. I had a lot of fun messing around with the anti-creeper there. Eventually, I learned that there was a Creeper World 3 hidden somewhere on the internet, and I looked everywhere for it. Soon, after visiting Knuckle Cracker's website[knucklecracker.com], I learned that Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal had been Greenlit on STEAM. I rushed to get a STEAM Card from Gamestop, and IMMEDIATELY bought Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal without even a second thought. When I started playing, I couldn't take my eyes off of the screen. Not for one second, not for my mom, not for my dad, not for my brother, not even to marvel at my chihuahua when he was rolling over in my room behind me, trying to get my attention. I could not stop for anyone. The story is amazingly well put together, and innovation and the quick thinking strategy it forces you to endorse while playing is absolutely indescribably amazing. I couldn't stop playing No matter how angry I got, or how far I progressed only to have the creeper destroy everything I have built and worked so hard for, I COULD NOT STOP PLAYING!! .... I'm sorry, if I keep this up, I'll be ranting on about how awesome this game is for days.

Posted: July 7, 2014
												A surprisingly satisfying experience, Creeper World 3 combines a compelling mystery-story about an enigmatic and impossibly powerful enemy with the satisfaction of a tower defense game that allows you to precisely nail that moment of satisfaction that comes when you just barely gain the upper hand, and turn the tables on an opponent that has had you against the ropes for most of the battle.......or at least that's what I experienced with my turtle-style gameplay; blocking off key points and slowly amassing an economic juggernaut that allows me to employ brute-force tactics and give the enemy a taste of his own medicine, so to speak. The story I found to be equally enjoyable, so much so that I found myself making sure to play through every planet of a given sector in a single session just so I could move on to the next and hear more of the narrative. It also included a worthwhile (if a bit predictable) twist at the end.9 / 10

Posted: April 23, 2014
												(Originally posted April 3 2014)I just finished the main campaign of Creeper World 3 today, a unique tower defense/RTS game that uses a thermodynamic simulation to control the "Creeper", a fluid–like substance that must be combatted to conquer the game's levels. A return to the top–down perspective of the original Creeper World, this game also incorporated many elements of the previous sequel, Creeper World 2 (which had a different perspective and significantly different mechanics).While I enjoyed this game very much, my biggest complaint is that the performance suffers when you have too many units built, which hampers my preferred turtle/juggernaut strategy. On some of the large maps, even playing at 4x speed the gameplay would slow to an interminable pace. Aside from that reservation, I'd certainly recommend this game, particularly to RTS and tower defense enthusiasts. The story is bat♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥crazy, but who plays this kind of game for the story?

Posted: June 4, 2014
												This game is so good!  It is by far the best of the Creeper World trilogy, all of which were highly enjoyable.  I completely devoured this game - I had a huge craving for a particular mood of space game, and this more than fit the bill.  The story is very compelling and almost haunting.  The incredibly far future setting is complemented superbly by the details and artifacts strewn across the many worlds.  Its practically awe-inspiring.Another thing I have to say about the game is that the design and coding is perfect - I never found a single bug, and was extremely pleased by all the things I could do with the interface that I wished I could have done in the predecessors. Posted: March 30, 2014
												Creeper World 3 is a fun and innovative take on the strategy/tower defense genre. Your main enemy is an ancient, liquid based entity that spreads throughout the universe, destroying all in its path. In order to kill the Creeper, you must build an energy network, build turrets to push it back, then destroy its source. There are a wide variety of tools at your disposal, various types of turrets, shields, terraforming devices, attack craft, and even the ability to manufacture your own creeper, to name a few. This creates considerable depth, by giving you the choice how to tackle the various missions.On the subject of missions, there are a lot of them. In addition to a main campaign (which does a good job of introducing players to the nuances of the game and the many units), there are several other sectors, numerous community made maps, and a dial a map function which allows for map generation. In short, there's a lot of hours fun to be had. In addition to great gamplay, the visuals are nice, and there's some really great music to play along to. I've encountered no bugs in my time playing. This is a game I would unconditionally recommend to strategy & tower defense fans. Even if strategy isn't normally your thing, CW3 is quite different from the usual fare, and you may well find something here to your liking. Well worth checking out!

Posted: June 12, 2015
												Quite the addictive Tower Defense esque game. I am writing tower defense esque, because you are not exactly fighting waves of enemies, but instead you are fighting waves of goo. The goo is generated by one or more spawner on a topographic map. The spawner acts as well for the liquid goo that is starting to slowly spread from its origin and you are tasked with destroying the spawner.In order to destroy the spawner you have to build an infrastructure that can fuel and provide your military forces (Towers) the necessary energy to stem the tide of the goo. You start from your own base/spaceship and extend from there, building collectors and relay stations in order to gather and transport energy to the guns. The guns once build have to be provided with energy in order to shoot. If the goo touches the base of the installation, the installation gets destroyed.As mentioned before, you are fighting on a tophographic map, which means every map has several layers and you can for example use the high advantage of a plateau in order to attack the goo beneath it. The goo, behaving like a liquid has to fill the entire level, before it can advance in height, which can be used by the player via terraforming the level.A quite addicting little game. Although, little might be a bit confusing. There seem to be at least 250 levels in the game, and for the hardcore, there are time attack leaderboards.

Posted: April 2, 2014
												I got this game when it first came out a while ago. So i have many hours playing it. The story is good but can get a little challenging if you mess up. Posted: November 27, 2015
												This is 3rd in the Creeper series and it shows; headline feature from previous entries now casually sit in your tool box, and years of polish and good UI choices run through the experience.This is the Creeper series at it's very best,The core game is a pseudo tower-defense game, where the enemy "creeper" is modeled on thermodynamic movement (enemy propagates through the level like heat through a medium), and your personal infrastructure in modeled on packet switching.The benefit of this is a game that's a very unique variant on the genre, and visually is wholly singular. Packets zip about your network as they beat back the horrors of living entropy!Worth highlighting is the story; minimalist in a very impressive way. A few text back-and-forths at the start of a level are all you get, but they deliver fully on the feeling and weight of being trapped at the end of a dead universe; alone in the empty infinity but for your sole friend.It would be nice if production values were a little higher. Sprites could be better; and the music though good, does get repetitive with it's few songs. Though the core experience is never deeply hurt by these weak points.The game's single biggest flaw is in it's dynamics. If you survive the first few minutes of a fight it becomes a rather rote process of slowly expanding your territory, until 30-60 min later you've zapped the last enemy. There are frequent small decisions to make, but very few large ones. Despite the narrative weight of the-end-of-all-things and the cool high-energy packet switching & blasting of your little empire, the game ultimately feels like a casual experience. Mellowly click away, pruning your little bonsai death machine until you've won. A fine experience, but RTS and 4x fans will be yearning for more difficulty and substance.Though some will wish it had more challenge, "Arc Eternal" is still an excellent little game! (And it's probably cheep by the time you read this.) Its uniqueness makes it well worth your time and money!

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Deceptively Simple. Truth be told, I thought this game was going to be some simple gimmick game, but the gameplay looked decent enough to try. Although the graphics aren't anything worthy of praise, it's an incredibly simple but effective demonstration of raw real time strategy gaming. The Campaign itself isn't too challenging, but beyond that there are tens and potentially even hundreds of missions which are playable beyond the Campaign, many of which are incredibly challenging in their own right. The economy system is incredibly similar to the likes of Supreme Commander. Posted: June 4, 2014
												Despite the title, this game has nothing to do with Minecraft! This is the first game I've bought in a long time at full price,  and it's worth every penny.Creeper World 3 is a pausable RTS-type game with aspects of tower defense at its core, combined with a physics/fluid dynamics twist. The game is very well done, challenging and packed with a number of game modes, along with a powerful integrated editor. It's not ridiculously complicated with dozens of units or a mad clickfest where you need millisecond reaction times to survive -- those games are not really my style, but Creeper World 3 is very satisfying. It can get hectic, but there's always time to pause and breathe.Terrain (including terraforming), energy networks and advancing your weaponry all play huge roles, and you will definitely be pondering strategies on every map. This is not a puzzler, there's not a single "right way" to win each map; given enough time, often times even poor strategies can grind out wins. That translates to a lot of flexibility and support for different playstyles and setups.As the title suggests, this is the third entry in the series, so there's a level of polish and streamlining over the previous titles. There are a huge number of community-created maps, variable-driven procedurally generated maps, and advanced scripting options available in the editor to create a large variety of scenarios beyond just basic maps. You could basically play this game for the rest of your life and always see new content. Steam cloud, achievements and online leaderboards round it all out.Try the free demo at the developer's site to see if it hooks you like it did me: http://knucklecracker.com/common/demo.php

Posted: July 27, 2015
												In three sentences this game is one of the best strategy games i have played in a long time. Taking a genre that has seen little inovation in recent years and turning it on its head. Expect a fun and challenging game, with an interesting story and a truly staggering amount of dev and user created levels. If you want a new challenge in a game type you like, then this RTS is well worth a try.A slightly more detailed opinion on the game is as follows.Creeper World 3 may be the third in a series but this is the first I heard of it. I enjoyed this game so much i really want to play the other two. The gameplay is fresh and an easy to follow inovation of traditional RTS's. With a story mode that doubles as a tutorial, new tech is introduced at a steady and not overwhelmin pace, but not too slow either. Instead of mining traditional resources you mine energy(for the most part) which maily takes space, the more space you have the more possible energy you can get, using traditional looking turrets and air craft you have to defend against an insidious liquid like enemy that flows from a central point, trying to take over the level. From a gameplay perspective this game is well worth a go if your a strategy fan, and if you simply want a game that provides a challenge without being overly frustrating then this may well be a good game for you.There are many features that will draw people from a leadership board, to simple but not old looking graphics, a different take on the RTS genre and of course the obscene amount of levels created by Devs and Users.On the probems side of this game, there are very few, there is one level that universaly hated for being bery hard and in many people's opinion impossible, this of course is wrong, its simply very hard. The repetative nature of so many guns constantly firing is very frustrating but they have made it easy to mute the sound. I certainly recomend this game as its deffinatly made it into my top favourate strategy games, and has just made it into my favourate games of all time. So what are you waiting for watch a video of the game and buy it. Its deffinatly worth the retail value, let alone a sale price

Posted: June 25, 2015
												Creeper World is a tower defense with very unique gameplay and design. Unlike most tower defense games your enemy isn't a horde of monsters, but is instead a steadily expanding mass known as 'creeper'. Defeating the creeper isn't as simple as having strong towers - you have to know how to hold back the creeper while expanding your own area of influence, taking into account the the creeper will ooze in from multiple angles and will build up in areas of low elevation to eventually climb up onto higher ground. Your own building mechanics are quite interesting as well. Instead of having independent towers, you instead build a web-like network of resource gatherers, utility structures, and attacking towers. Managing this web can get quite tricky at times, because all resources must flow through a command center and take time to traverse the network. Done incorrectly you could end up building a tower but not being able to arm it in time to defend against the creeper. Also, while the creeper acts as a steadily growing mass, the player often ends up mirroring the creeper in many ways. Collectors - the primary resource generator - are most effective when spread out, forcing the player to expand their area of influence if they want more resources to spend. There are also many resource deposits around the map which must be contested, forcing the player to expand their area of influence even more. Aiding this playstyle is the fact that attacking towers can be respositioned, allowing you to leapfrog towers to slowly but steadily push the creeper back.Overall the game is an excellent example of a unique twist on a genre and very polished gameplay. It's an extremely satisfying game to play and I highly recommend it to anyone who finds the concept interesting. Don't worry about not playing the previous games - they give more of the story, but this game is fully functional as a standalone experience.

Posted: June 14, 2015
												Hello, guys!I really can't even how good this game is. I've played CW2 before, so I didn't hesitate to buy this game as soon as I've noticed it.What is CW all about? It's an interesting strategy, where you don't fight against enemy units similar to yours, but massive amounts of creeping blue goo. So it feels a little bit like tower defence, but really innovative one.The in-game economy system is quite simmilar to one from Supreme Commander (which I loved too!) and it's based more on flow of the resources than stockpiling them. This approach forces costant action, which is nice.So, does concept still feels to You boring? Fear not, as so far every single map is quite diverse and suprises me with something new (I've completed about 30% of game, and CW2 which was quite brilliant too!). Your enemy sometimes spawns various units too, and the goo doesn't always act like it's expected to. The game has its own plot, which is not that plain. There are no cosmic civilisations fighting against each other. There's no war, humanity lost against creeper long ago. You've been asleep for 5 billion years. All you can do is crawling through ruins of ceased race of humans, and try to make sense of what happened. Why do I even mention history in such simple game? Honestly, because at this point I am simply curious how will this story end.The only 2 downsides I've noticed are:-crappy, plain graphics. I don't think it matters though, as this simpleness comes in one package with perfect gameplay and practical interface.-lack of multiplayer. Seriously, guys, I don't care, add it somehow!What do I say at the end? Mabye I'll describe my general feel about it. This game feels like the best flash game ever, but with large campagin and saving and stuff. Buy it. Do it. I don't think anyone would regret doing it, except if it makes him fail his exams or sth.

Posted: May 8, 2014
												I've been very interested in the Creeper World trilogy for as long as I can possibly remember. I first found a flash game affixed on the engine used in Creeper World 1, Creeper World Training Simulation[www.kongregate.com] on Kongregate, and ever since then I had been searching vigeriously for more Creeper World flash games. Next up was another game created by the engine used for Creeper World 1, Creeper World: Evermore[www.kongregate.com]. Following up on that, I also discovered Creeper World: User Space[www.kongregate.com]. Shortly after, I finally found a flash game affixed to the engine Creeper World 2 was made from, Creeper World 2: Academy[www.kongregate.com]. I had a lot of fun messing around with the anti-creeper there. Eventually, I learned that there was a Creeper World 3 hidden somewhere on the internet, and I looked everywhere for it. Soon, after visiting Knuckle Cracker's website[knucklecracker.com], I learned that Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal had been Greenlit on STEAM. I rushed to get a STEAM Card from Gamestop, and IMMEDIATELY bought Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal without even a second thought. When I started playing, I couldn't take my eyes off of the screen. Not for one second, not for my mom, not for my dad, not for my brother, not even to marvel at my chihuahua when he was rolling over in my room behind me, trying to get my attention. I could not stop for anyone. The story is amazingly well put together, and innovation and the quick thinking strategy it forces you to endorse while playing is absolutely indescribably amazing. I couldn't stop playing No matter how angry I got, or how far I progressed only to have the creeper destroy everything I have built and worked so hard for, I COULD NOT STOP PLAYING!! .... I'm sorry, if I keep this up, I'll be ranting on about how awesome this game is for days.

Posted: November 30, 2015
												If you're a fan of tower defence games then I highly recommend you try this, especially if you're looking for something different.Gameplay: 8/10Visuals: 5/10Story: TL;DR/10The gameplay is an excellent take on the tower defence genre. Your enemy flows like water over the mountains and vallies of the terrain as you fight them back and shape the terrain to keep them out and direct the flow as you pierce forward to destroy their source. Gameplay is kept interesting through unique gameplay elements on specific maps (Such as a map with an orbiting planet past the borders that attracts the tide of enemies towards it as it spins) and a decent array of towers which offer multiple ways to complete any challenge.The visuals are what let this game down and make it feel like someone's first tower defence game made in flash, at first glance. Pixel art while low resolution can be hard to master, having the visuals of a game like FTL would make this game look incredible.Gameplay tips:Terps can be toggled between shaping layers or the closest blockSprayers can be set to "always on", I suggest flooding your base with AC and letting it overflow to expand your bordersDon't be afraid to pause and plan with TAB or PSet up a few Berthas and aim them at spawn points, with enough you will slowly drain the map

												It's been a while since I played this one, but saw this on sale and got shivers... yeah nothing beats blasting away unimaginable amouns of goo out of existence using cannons capable of dismantling a planet.Price is right, looks are simple, gameplay is solid and goo is sticky - 9 elevation levels out of 10.

Posted: November 27, 2015
												This is 3rd in the Creeper series and it shows; headline feature from previous entries now casually sit in your tool box, and years of polish and good UI choices run through the experience.This is the Creeper series at it's very best,The core game is a pseudo tower-defense game, where the enemy "creeper" is modeled on thermodynamic movement (enemy propagates through the level like heat through a medium), and your personal infrastructure in modeled on packet switching.The benefit of this is a game that's a very unique variant on the genre, and visually is wholly singular. Packets zip about your network as they beat back the horrors of living entropy!Worth highlighting is the story; minimalist in a very impressive way. A few text back-and-forths at the start of a level are all you get, but they deliver fully on the feeling and weight of being trapped at the end of a dead universe; alone in the empty infinity but for your sole friend.It would be nice if production values were a little higher. Sprites could be better; and the music though good, does get repetitive with it's few songs. Though the core experience is never deeply hurt by these weak points.The game's single biggest flaw is in it's dynamics. If you survive the first few minutes of a fight it becomes a rather rote process of slowly expanding your territory, until 30-60 min later you've zapped the last enemy. There are frequent small decisions to make, but very few large ones. Despite the narrative weight of the-end-of-all-things and the cool high-energy packet switching & blasting of your little empire, the game ultimately feels like a casual experience. Mellowly click away, pruning your little bonsai death machine until you've won. A fine experience, but RTS and 4x fans will be yearning for more difficulty and substance.Though some will wish it had more challenge, "Arc Eternal" is still an excellent little game! (And it's probably cheep by the time you read this.) Its uniqueness makes it well worth your time and money!

												It's a lot of fun, and for the price I got it at I feel well rewarded.The game plays like there's some kind of weird oil leak most of the time, and it's our job to keep the goo at bay and fight our way to the source.  Unfortunately the game rarely extends beyond that so once you've managed to create a stable defense it can get a little dull.Story missions vary it up more so it's less predictable and forces you to stay on your toes.I personally love this game because it can scratch that one itch we all have for a casual, but tough strategy game.

Posted: February 4, 2016
Because of this game Steam is convinced that I like Tower Defence games...I don't, I just like Creeper World series, that's it.In Creeper World games, you set up energy collection grid and use collected energy to beat back titular creeper, the blue, oozing fluid whose behaviour (according to extras from CW1) is described by modified heat transfer equations. Every building and weapon costs energy to build, and most cost energy to maintain, forcing you to constantly expand to new areas to build new collectors/reactors to beat creeper back by few tiles more until you can escape (CW1) or kill it for good (CW2/CW3)That's it. But the way Creeper interacts with shape of the map means that there's a lot of strategy involved: where do you set up a defence? Can you cover the valley with collectors AND fortify it before creeper floods it? Do you go for tight grid of expensive but efficient and easily defensible reactors or for wide and redundant but hard to defend net of collectors? What combination of weapons will you use? How many blasters? Mortars? Sprayers? Maybe use Bombers, Strafers and Cargo planes to open another front on top of the hill instead of fighting uphill? How do you handle valley and mountain ranges?Not to mention player-made maps of all sorts, including puzzles, "play as creepers" and tricky maps with lots of unexpected scripting.Bonus highlight of the game is CRPL = Creeper Reverse Polish Language, a built-in scripting language giving map creators total control, even roguelike maps can be made.I wholeheartedly recommend entire series, available from creator's page. Only latest instalment is on Steam.

Arc Eternal builds on that same concept.There is an enjoyable trance this game seems to lull me into. It feels like a familiar formula, but plays out in a nuanced and original fashion.15 bucks is a pretty steep price for what it is imo, so I would snag it on a sale. I'd drop a 5 dollar bill on it any day though.

Posted: October 26, 2014
												A seemingly simple, easy to pick up RTS with mechanics that afford incredible depth. Reminiscent of Total Annihilation (intentionally so, given the inclusion of the signature bertha cannon) and the under appreciated gem perimeter. There is a great amount of value here for a game of this type. Each level in the campaign introduces a new unit or a new mechanic or just has some kind of unique property to make it interesting which is really the key to any decent RTS campaign. After you 'finish' the main story there is a bounty of user designed maps, wacky beta tester maps and 2 'sectors' of conventional maps with a specific goal in mind, not to mention the ability to design your own maps. Not only is the replay potential limitless it's also really good content in its own right, some of the use made maps are really fun and if you beat it in the fastest time you get to 'claim' it as your own.If you're into oldschool RTS like red alert 2, starcraft or the aforementioned TA this the ultimate indie game, you wont get a better experience for your money.  I honestly can't believe this was developped by one guy given the amount of content squeezed in and the elegance of the design.

Posted: April 3, 2014
												Unique and addicting, this tower defense game ranks up there with the very best in its genre.  Instead of fighting off enemies one at a time while they march on a base, this game has players holding back seas of purple slime.  Depth, density, and volume are all significant factors when planning your strategy against the slime emanating from various points on each map.  Where players are usually expected to only defend their base in traditional tower defense games, Creeper World has the added final, and extremely satisfying, goal of pushing through the slime and destroying the source. If that was all there was to this game it could still easily be considered great; its community support through the map editor and its features however, makes it fantastic.  Players can create generated maps according to specified criteria, design maps from scratch themselves, and then upload all of these in-game to be played by the community.  It's one of the most simple and easy to use map editors I've used - I just jumped right in and never even looked at the tutorial.If you like tower defense games, this is one you want for your collection.  And if you don't like tower defense games and you're still reading this review it's probably because your noticing how uniquely awesome this game is and you haven't even played it yet.

Fending off blue goo is fun, but what if you want red goo? You can even customize the colour of the creep! It's really cool and super fun to play. Not for casual gamers or hardcore shooter fans but if you like strategy games this will take you to a new level of tower defense.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												This game has a thrilling story with a presentation that I absolutely love in strategy games, and it reminds me in this of one of my favorite RTS games, the first StarCraft. The gradual tech and story progression with each - sometimes long, sometimes difficult - mission, adapting to and overcoming the new challenge, is just very enjoyable for me. Now that I finished the campaign, though, I feel I have only scratched the game's surface. With all the user-created maps, and extra map packs the game provides, I am already returning for more challenges.A criticism I'm reading in the negative reviews is how the game is the same grind all over again. Building up basic macro and defenses, and then progressing with micro as you upgrade your tech. For a game where every map is different, leaving a wide array of viable strategies and tactics to the player, I find this a very bad point. The SupCom-esque resource system, the focus on map control and relentless assault make this game very interesting, and even the initial 'always repeated' steps come in a personal flavor and depend on the map. The graphics may look abstract and weird in the screenshots, but they quickly make sense when playing the game. The terrain layers are also very consistent. And honestly, I found a salvo of Bertha shots' dispersed Creeper very satisfying to watch. There's few things like it.If you're interested, watch some gameplay videos or just wait for a decent sale. I got it at -90% so sales do get decent! There's little room for disappointment at that price, and maybe it will cause you yourself to write a positive review in time.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												One of the best and most unique indie games I've played.  While on its surface it may only look like a simple tower defense game, it brings an incredibly unique spin to the genre by completely removing the upfront cost for buildings in favor of an energy management system, and by having a fluid enemy.  Endlessly replayable, with hundreds of included maps, and thousands more community-made maps available for download.  And if that's still not enough, it comes with a map editor and a procedural map generator, which allows for essentially limitless possibilities.  Don't worry if you've never played Creeper World 1 or 2, the early missions have a tutorial, which walks you through the possible uses for each building.

Posted: November 8, 2014
												I've always had a thing for RTS and Tower Defense games, and so when I first found Creeper World on Kongregate, I was overjoyed. There were many different versions available freely there. Recently, I decided to purchase the third installment to see how it was.There is much to love about this game. The game follows more or less the same rules throughout, but the final two story missions are definite game changers. I've seen many complain about losing on the second to last mission due to time constraints - I myself lost the first time around, but with a little advice I figured out how to beat it. The consistency of the gameplay can make things a little drab if you play too much, but if you enjoy one level, you're likely to enjoy a whole lot more - and there are a whole lot more. There's an practically endless array of levels once you beat most of the story. You can binge play or play a game every once in a while - either way, it will take you a long time to run out of official maps, and you'll never run out of custom ones. The game isn't all too challenging if you remember to pause frequently and keep tabs on the Creeper and your resources, but there are more difficult levels available if that's what you're looking for. The graphics are solid - nothing incredible, but well-done nonetheless.

Posted: October 26, 2014
												A seemingly simple, easy to pick up RTS with mechanics that afford incredible depth. Reminiscent of Total Annihilation (intentionally so, given the inclusion of the signature bertha cannon) and the under appreciated gem perimeter. There is a great amount of value here for a game of this type. Each level in the campaign introduces a new unit or a new mechanic or just has some kind of unique property to make it interesting which is really the key to any decent RTS campaign. After you 'finish' the main story there is a bounty of user designed maps, wacky beta tester maps and 2 'sectors' of conventional maps with a specific goal in mind, not to mention the ability to design your own maps. Not only is the replay potential limitless it's also really good content in its own right, some of the use made maps are really fun and if you beat it in the fastest time you get to 'claim' it as your own.If you're into oldschool RTS like red alert 2, starcraft or the aforementioned TA this the ultimate indie game, you wont get a better experience for your money.  I honestly can't believe this was developped by one guy given the amount of content squeezed in and the elegance of the design.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												SUMMARY: A unique and interesting RTS/tower defense sci-figame. You use nodes to create webs which energy then passes through to power your weapons/defenses and beat back the ever-encroaching purple creeper "mist". Its addictive and you will have the temptation to go "one more level" everyime you think you're going to quit. The graphics and sound are adequate, but not great, But who plays these games for the graphics? If you are an RTS/TD fan, this game is defintely one to pick up even at full price. It's tiny bit pricy at full price for those who arent die-hard fans of RTS/TD games, but if you see it on sale, get it!MAIN:This game is fascinating. Its a really unique RTS/tower defense, the style of which vaguely reminds me of the Zerg in the original Starcraft. But there are no barracks for units, no movable parts. No vespene gas.You have awoken in space after a 5-billion(!?) year stasis sleep, to find that the Creeper has again rampaged around destroying humanity's galactic empire. Of course, you must stop them. Its kind of difficult to explain how this game works without seeing it, but I'll do my best:The Creepers have emitters which slowly start filling the map with purple stuff. If this purple stuff touches one of your buildings it is destroyed. You need to destroy all the emitters to progress. Sometimes there are other objectives as well.So you build a command center far away from the emitters. Then you start building nodes and weapons such as cannons. Each node creates lines to the nodes next to it, and power flows through these lines from the command center to your weapons/cannons as well as newly placed buildings to construct them. Cannons cant link to each other, but only to nodes and relay nodes. So you want to build as many nodes to create a web, then a front line of weapons to hold off the onslaught, slowly building more relay nodes and weapons as you manage to beat back the "purple mist". The nodes also generate energy, which you need to power your cannons and build things quickly. Build too fast, and your energy goes out of balance, weakening the ammo resupply to your cannons and allowing the evil purple stuff to overrun them.There are also specialty nodes, such as relays which speed up energy transmission to new nodes and weapons, reactors, which provide lots of energy, special weapons, and many others I havent seen yet.Theres a lot of strategy, figuring out the best place to put your nodes to create fast transmission of power as well as beat back the purple mist, but not overbuilding so you end up overrun. Missions are timed, although as of yet I havent seen any where you "must beat the mission in (x) amount of time", but I wouldnt be surprised if they were out there (I hate those types of missions...I'm naturally a careful player who tries to do/see everything in any game I play. I HATE being rushed.). The fun of being timed is a global leaderboard where you can see rankings of how fast people have beat the missions.The graphics are nothing to write home about, just little representations of the terrain, units, your node web, claimed territories, ect. But who cares? The strategy is what matters here, and I'll take gameplay over graphics any day of the year.Sound is the same as graphics. Its ok, but nothing spectacular. Lots of pew pew and booms.Overall, this is a unique and interesting game. There appear to be many many levels to play as well as a storyline. Its really fun, and if you see it on sale is a must buy for any RTS/tower defense fan.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												A good game, but with issues in its "packaging".I knew the series from the previous Flash chapters. The developer did a good job adding enough elements to this episode to keep the gameplay interesting throughout the campaign.It's an interesting strategy game, where you know how the enemy will behave from the start (since it follows fluid physics) and yet every map requires you to think about how to approach it with the land provided and the techs unlocked. The gameplay is solid, it is decently challenging for a first walkthrough (yet nothing a player with any experience in the genre will not be able to tackle) and offers a chance for speedrunning/score attack replays of existing maps. Apart from the campaign (which took me somewhere between 8 and 10 hours at a leisurly pace), the game has a couple extra modes with different objectives, for even more longevity.The problems I have with the game are mostly outside of the gameplay itself. The game asks for a relatively high price tag for a series evolved from a Flash game, but does it add enough to make it reasonable? In my eyes, it doesn't.The storyline is ridiculous, it pretty much revolves for the entire campaign around the idea of "I lost my memory, what's all of this?". You could skip every dialogue in the game and not miss anything relevant. The only campaign progression is the gradual introduction of more buildings and techs.Which leads to the second point: after you unlock everything and you figure out which approach works best for you, most of the extra modes are more of the same. Which is good if you want to play more on different maps, but it lacks the tailored scenarios of the campaign. Still, it's good to come back from time to time for a map or two and have a large selection of unexplored locations.The graphics haven't improved in a relevant way compared to the Flash chapters. The soundtrack is very limited and you will get bored of the few track really fast.All things considered it's still a game I'd pick up, but at a sensible discount, since it's reasonably fun to play for a while but lacks the added value to justify the price point.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
Creeper World 3 is quite a unique game, it feels like a tower defense game mixed with real-time-strategy elements.Like in most other RTS games, you have to build a base, though here it is more like a 'power grid', which is essential to power all your defensive and offensive structures. The main difference here though, is the enemy. Instead of tanks, humans or monsters, you have a lava like liquid, that slowly creeps its way to your base and tries to 'fill' the entire map.It's called 'The Creeper'. I know, it sounds like the name of a cheap 60s horror movie, but it's not.Anyways, most of the time you'll build turrets, mortars, jet fighters and bombers to defend yourself from The Creeper. But usually that's not enough. You also have the option to 'terraform' the environment. That way you can either dig trenches, or, which is a lot more effective, raise the terrain to wall off your base.The whole process is quite a lot of fun, especially when you unlock things like the Bertha, which is a giant cannon, or the Thor, which is a giant spaceship with multiple turrets that rains death from above.The thing I like the most about Creeper World 3 is that you can play whatever way you like. This might be the slow and defensive way, or the fast and offensive way. This is quite important if you care about getting in the top 10 list of each map. These lists are primarily sorted by how much time it took you to complete the map, though to be honest, you'll have a hard time beating the best times, since they're usually around 20 to 30 seconds for each map. This is especially frustrating because I doubt those times are legit most of the time.All in all though, Creeper World 3 features a huge amount of content, which is good if you like getting your money worth. It's also bad if you want to 100% this game, because judging by the amount of levels, it might take you hundreds of hours to do so.There's also the fact that you can make your own maps, and play other players maps right inside the game. This gives Creper World 3 almost infinitive content, though some player created levels might be too easy, or even impossible to beat.Conclusion: Amazing game with an enormous amount of re-playability, easily worth the full price if you're a fan of tower-defense/RTS type of games.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												So, first things first, this game is not the best written and graphically designed, and that probably turns some people off. I am very pleased that I fall outside of that group because it is a terrific game. The basic mechanics are all easy to understand, shooting the creeper makes it decrease in level, creeper moves like a fluid (though I've heard it's simulated more like heat. But for all gameplay purposes you can think of it like a viscous fuid) to fill in gaps, you need to send out packets made from energy to supply turrets, construction and other things. Then as these gameplay elements start to overlap the interactions between them get more complex. I won't go into too much detail but there is a special type of terrain that promotes the creeper to flow along it. This may completely throw what you were doing previously because suddenly you have to be cautious with the fact that it is much harder to clear the creeper.The main draw of the game to me was the resource management system though, which forces you to manage between the space needed to get energy, how much you can afford to defend with that energy, and how you can expand from there. It is very easy to find you've just spent half an hour gradually shifting around units to allow you to push forwards, but all of that time feels engaging.Overall it's a very engaging game and at £12 it's decently priced for the amount of gameplay contained within.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Creeper World combines strategy, resource management, and meditation.Ok, technically you can just crank up the speed to remove some of the meditative aspects, but usually on those levels I'm too busy micromanaging my energy flow moment by moment to do that.If you've played the other Creeper World titles you'll already be familiar with the franchise approach - the enemy is simply evil water, and you're equipped with a variety of anti-water weaponry that costs energy to use, while you seek to reach and destroy the faucets that spawn your dire nemesis.With a reasonable single player campaign and a huge quantity of additional levels, there's plenty to keep you busy.  Level quality can vary a great deal, with some really clever ones, and some that are truly just boring, with little to warn you which will be which. Even so, if you enjoy this sort of challenge, you'll find you have a lot of quiet moments of personal accomplishment where you puzzle out some elaborate resource management or timing issue.  The game has a lot of depth, and even once you've polished off the campaign, there is loads more playtime to be had.Overall, good stuff.  If you enjoy strategic puzzles and resource management then this is an easy buy.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												I used to play this ditty on Kongregate! KnuckleCracker still knows how to impress.You've watched the gameplay, you get the concept - you're fighting a blob; storyline irrelevent. Figure out where to land your HQ and lay out some power infrastructure. Get to the point you can build two power structures at once, build a few sets of two. Construct a laser and mortar, click "stop resupply" and when they're built - figure out which one you need first - click "disarm" and then "resupply" and then do the same for the second weapon. Construct a third weapon, your choice, I prefer mortars over lasers 4/1 so I'd make two mortars.The trick with mortars and your power supply is, they recharge faster than they fire. So you can pinch off their supply, use it to construct and power other buildings, and stop them - then resupply the mortars more quickly than over-loading your entire power supply would. By playing "half-court" with the power supply, I have been able to greatly improve my speed. Some levels that I've thought were impossible, I've re-visited and been able to beat; some are still impossible.Some cheats must exist because of high scores. High scores mean nothing though. You play, you win and lose, you have fun, you get frustrated, you leave, you come back and figure out a new layout or move on. It's a good game. I play it often - I mute the music and watch TV on an adjacent screen though. Too much of the music will kill your brain like bathsalts.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												I never played the first two Creeper World games. I didn’t even know Creeper World was a thing, it flew so far below my radar. The third came highly recommended to me by someone and it was on sale, so I figured why not. Trying new things is part of the fun of gaming. Thankfully, you don’t need to have played either of the previous games to enjoy Creeper World 3, as it has a mostly self-contained plot.There’s no getting around it: the game looks ugly. The graphics are utterly functional, and that’s it. But this ugly duckling has a supernova of elegant swans that explode from its superdense core the moment you start playing. Arc Eternal follows a well-written science-fiction plot as you fight an enigmatic foe known only as “Creeper”.You can place turrets, mortar launchers, build bombers, cannons, and terraform the terrain to redirect the Creeper’s endless flow, provided you have the resource generating capacity to sustain it all. By the end of a mission, the sheer scope of your network of energy-producing Collectors can be impressive.The campaign is lengthily with many unique map elements. There’s a huge amount of side-missions and bonus content if you’re up for it, and the Dial-a-Map Device can generate infinite random missions.  Creeper World 3 is impressive where it truly counts.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Contrary to "overwhelmingly positive" status, i am going to give the game a downvote.Everything that is written in positive reviews is true, except for one thing:Unless you are looking for some kind of self employed challenge (win before certain time limit for example), every single map (with exceptions where it is not possible by design) is winnable with:Build reactors, mortars, more reactors, do some upgrades, then more mortars, and more mortars and MORE mortars.And that is is, no challenge, no evolving A.I., no strategy required. Other units are useless and unused - well, again if they are not needed by map design.You have to employ snipers on maps with "bugs", anti-air guns where you are being pressed by spores, and planes/berthas on maps made of "islands". But that does not change your strategy, it just adds a tiny mix of certain type of gun to the "build mortars and win".The only mission i actually had to adjust over time was the last mission of the main story AGAINST Loki. But even then it was just a bigger mix in overwelmingly prevaling "mortar combat".So after a certain time the game becomes dull and the only challenge are map conditions where you are forced to do something before you can "mortar them all".It is a shame, really. The overall concept is very nice.---- SPOILER ALERT ----And i was able to win last mission as Emperor doing this:Move around not to get hit and destroy the right lower AA gun.Place the ship outside the range of other guns.Set time to 4x (only needed to make things quicker.Press the mouse button that fires the gun (and leave it pressed whichever way you like), so the creep is constantly renewed below the gunshots.8Hrs later (2Hrs on 4x speed) - victory, the map was  completely flooded by the creep :)The only thing interesting about it was to see how the creep and anticreep collide and how the "fluid physics" works in game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												So far i'm loving this game, i picked it up during the steam sales for like 2 bucks but its worth so much more than that. The gameplay is a interesting mix of towerdefence\survival\rts similar to infested planet but controlling structures instead of a moving team, if you enjoyed infested planet i'd highly recommend this. The approaching doom of the creeper goo gives you a survival feeling i haven’t seen many games be able to recreate.While i'm a firm advocate of "gameplay before graphics", i can’t help but feel that this game deserves better graphics, not to say that the gameplay is effected, but the gameplay is so nicely polished it would be great to see graphics that match the high level of gameplay, Its ovbious that the creator is probbly more comfortable with programming (I'm sorry if you're not!) which isnt nessisarily a bad thing because the gameplay makes up for it massivly, but the graphics in their current state are kind of plain and the looming doom of the creeper sludge or whatever it is, isn’t quite captured as well in its current opaque single colour state. Regardless I’ve been enjoying the hell out of the gameLastly, i would love to see more types of items to defend with, aside from using the anticreeper goo turrets and the jets, i found the game mostly revolved around the standard turrets and mortars, with some specialty units thrown in that are only situational, they're fun but more variation would be nice. Also the block building thing is overpowered as hell, really needs some sorta finite resorce to stop you from just cheezing it and building a 10 high bridge all the way to the spawners, i'd like to see it cost more or be limited somehow because it makes defending way too easy, maybe combine it with the ore production so it costs a bit more, I’m a bit of a turtle style builder but this gives you way too much control. But yeah buy this game!!

number of helpful: 82 of 166 people (49%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												After having read the enthusiastic user reviews, i was sure to have a lot of fun with this game.Some hours later, i cant exactly share this view.The games plays always the same: Protect yourself to a degree, where the enemy (brainless creep, which just grows) isnt able to get in your base, then destroy him step by step. I really am missing some personality, some intelligent behavior, like f.e. in Ai War.Dont get me wrong, its not a bad game. But it is not a great game as well, but just another turret offense/defense game, which additionaly suffers under terrible graphics and a bad interface.I seriously cannot recommend it for the price of 15$, regarding what (great) games you get for that amount.Still, if you can live with the terrible presentation, and regarding the playtime you will have with this game, easily a couple of dozens of hours, just to finish the campaign, and after that, dozens of user-made content awaits, i can recommend this game, if you find it on sale...

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												It's an okay game. The mechanics are a fun take on the traditional tower defense game, and there are a lot of different buildings available. However, the game turns into a grind fest after you stabilize on a level. The formula is: buy as much econ as you can without dying, then at the last second buy towers to keep yourself alive. Sometimes this is difficult, but I rarely lost levels except for when the layout was something I hadn't seen before (for example, some levels have space between usable areas of land). As long as you don't overbuild, there are almost no scenarios where a previously defended area will get overwhelmed. It would be nice if there was better scaling over time or perhaps momentum mechanics (so if you screw up while expanding it can cause damage to the rest of your structure). I'm probably only 1/3rd of the way through the game, but it's gotten a bit too repetitive to see through. Oh well. Don't recommend unless you're looking for a side game while watching netflix or something.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
What I liked: Simple Concept, Challenging Gameplay Good variety in weapon for TD(Tower Defence) Open ended stratergiesWhat You Need to Know: This is a hybrid of a TD and RTS, you use towers and ships, but there are no lanes and level up of  towers Your main enemy is the creep, which is a purple fliud that is like a great wall that is constantly attacking you You do have other things that mix up the the enemy tactics, such as spore towers, difficult spider web bridge things with stunning robot spiders and a few others You can make your own maps with a built in editor, which is easy to use or just use the random generator to quickly play limiteless maps, and even play other peoples maps There is no one way to win the maps, you can play it like you want, not forcing you down one path to beat a mission Your main goal in every mission is to destroy the creep spawners, and other towers, leaving a ring behind for each one that you can use to upgrade whatever turret placed in it.( SUPERCHARGE BABY!!) One of my personal favorite TD/RTS games I played this game alot already before on steam ( So hours played is not my true time) A game that can be as easy as you want or as complicated as you want to make itMy Score:A+Paid $1.50Completed in: 15 hours/b]Games similar:  Infested Planet Supreme Commander AI War: Fleet Command

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												8/10In Creepers your constantly under attack from a constant flow of blue mass, rather than the traditional waves of enemies, it's your task to hold it back while gathering items or force you way into the mass, to blow it all up.creepers is a breath of fresh tower-defense-air, every level present you with an interesting story and exiting challenges, the play style is casual, build your defense and slowly progress towards your goals, this game is really about defense, there's nothing more enjoyable, than slowly progressing into the 'blue' by moving towers, shoot a path, build platforms and repeat, sounds a bit boring?, but it's far from it. Creepers is all game mechanics, something it does very very well, graphics is not worth talking about, like in Prison architecture it does it's job and works flawless, it's not in the way and you quickly forget about it, still i would like to see some improvement here.The campaign offers hours of challenging game-play, if that's not enough for, there are hundreds of levels build by users.so why not 10 of 10, on game-play i'll give it a 9.5, but this is the third game in the series, you would think by now graphics would be on the agenda, especially the interface, which is a big mess, it never went beyond the mockup stage, which is sad, because it sends a signal that "we just don't care", they should.there are much more to be said about Creepers, but honestly i'll rather play the game than write about it, so off i go.if you like tower defense games and games like Infested planet, this one is for you, but be warned, it is a time-robber ;).

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												I'm enjoying this game, but I really don't like being forced to go through the campaign (which has levels that can become quite tedious).  There's no access to some advertised features until the campaign is finished.Okay - if the campaign is good, let it stand on its own two feet.  Don't use it as a "job" the player has to work through in order to get to the features that looked interesting.WHAT THE GAME HAS TO OFFER:This is a subtle balancing act between building up energy and mining operations at the right pace versus building up weaponry.  What I like about this game is the subtlety.  You might be tempted to build a lot of things only to run out of energy and then nothing gets done.There are also interesting fluid dynamics to work with/against.

Regardless I’ve been enjoying the hell out of the gameLastly, i would love to see more types of items to defend with, aside from using the anticreeper goo turrets and the jets, i found the game mostly revolved around the standard turrets and mortars, with some specialty units thrown in that are only situational, they're fun but more variation would be nice. Also the block building thing is overpowered as hell, really needs some sorta finite resorce to stop you from just cheezing it and building a 10 high bridge all the way to the spawners, i'd like to see it cost more or be limited somehow because it makes defending way too easy, maybe combine it with the ore production so it costs a bit more, I’m a bit of a turtle style builder but this gives you way too much control. But yeah buy this game!!

												Really great game. You can play very fast by utilizing the pause button often, or you can play methodically slow on most missions. Creeper world 3 offers tons of play hours, new content and challenges. The steam achievements for the game are well thought out, with a variety of achievements focused on different aspects of the game, and at different difficulties. The story is brilliant. Unlocking tech gives you an incentive to keep playing, and each mission reveals more of the story so that you can't wait to get to the next planet to discover what comes next. There are even options to finish the story in a different way. Overall this is the best $5.00 I spent on steam, and I love every aspect of the game.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												The perfect blend of RTS and Tower Defence. Each level is unique and can be completed in many different ways. The story is more or less interesting, and as you progress - many additional modes open up with hundreds of new levels. There are literally millions of user-created levels, and an editor for you to create your own levels. The graphics aren't in a very good resolution, but that's not a big deal, the general concept is nice and everything is pretty beautiful. You can easily loose dozens of hours on this, it makes you want to come back, even after some time. Definetly recommended, worth every cent!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I was pleasantly surprised by Creeper World 3. I've always been a fan of tower defense style games, and creeper world mixes up the formula a bit, adds a few elements that are almost puzzle-like, and ties the whole package up with a story that I found novel and refreshing. There are no "lanes" or marching mindless enemies, but there is a network of towers that will desperately fire a nonstop barrage to hold back the enemy long enough for a careful strike against their resource nodes. You hope. For a faceless enemy, you truly feel like you are facing down an infinite and eternal threat. There was never any hope for survivival in this unforgiving universe, but you will carve out a section of peace in your small quadrant for as long as you are able. For what alternative can there be.AI War is similar, and a little bit better, but I am glad I stubmled upon this all the same.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												Having completed the story campaign (20ish missions of 15-40mins each) I found myself more annoyed than pleased.The problem lies in the fact that to once the initial rush of the creeper is stopped (first 5-10 mins of a map) the map is essentially won, and yet after that point 3/4 or more, ones time is simply grinding the rest of the map down.Now this can be said for many games, but they often have some diversity in the opposition or tricks up their sleeves that might turn things around. No so here, the "water/fluid" bases enemy is faceless and anonymous, simply a fluid that floods the map as water poured over a surface would. It never does something as such. It is simply there and spreads a poodle, that your job is to clean up.So once the initial rush (catching the falling pitcher of water before it floods your house) is over, you then spend some very real world boring time cleaning up, lots and lots of it.That is not to say it is a bust, It'd actually go for a neutral on it if I could, since it does have its ups too. But in the end I plunged for a thumbs down for the simple reason that games should not be work, but entertainment, this one lacks a middle game and end game on the maps to be the latter instead of the prior.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												I love tower and defense type games especially the ones with high complexity. For all of Creeper World's unique building types, interesting building connections, and neat other ideas -- you're still fighting water. The story tries to turn the "purple water" into a menacing all encompassing alien blob, but it doesn't behave like one. Heck, the water moves in a really non-aggressive way like waves lapping at the shore. If you want a game with AI that adpats to your playstyle, look elsewhere.The most stressful time in any given match is the first few minutes when you're building your base up. I've hit restart numerous times because of acting too slow (mostly since I'm watching TV at the same time); however, once you're up and running defeating creeper is not really about strategy or skills, it's more like a waiting game. You'll be slowly grinding out the time of waiting for buildings to construct or moving your buildings around. The only way this game is interesting is that it allows speed players to post their completion times for everyone to see.While I do fawn over pixel art, Creeper World is very dated even for pixel graphics. There are loads more mobile games that look better than this. I will say that the strongest aspect of the aesthetic is the soundtrack. I never felt bored with the music and it gives this emergency type of rock background in the environment. Nontheless I turned it off so I could watch TV and youtube.

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												tl;dr: I paid 2 euros for it. Got my money's worth but not much more than that.One of the more innovative takes on the tower defense genre, but not without its flaws. There are no waves, just the relentless Creeper that keeps flooding the levels at a more or less steady rate. Meanwhile, the player builds all manner of defenses and the infrastructure to support it. It becomes a tug-of-ware between how much creeper is created and the player's ability to destroy it. Due to this mechanic, the hard part is usually the beginning, the containment of the creeper. Once that's done, the player would begin building more and more weapons to turn the tide in his favor. It gets a bit redundant, but luckily the devs have spiced things up a little with creative level design.But that's just one way of playing the game. The other is to rush everything in minutes and ignore most of the depth the game has to offer. The worst part is that the tactic for rushing is pretty much always the same.Having spent hours defeating single levels with the first method, I feel kind of cheated. I like the base building aspect in games, because it's rewarding to see the tide turn in your favor. But why would you do that if you can negate the tide before it rises up?

number of helpful: 7 of 25 people (28%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
Creeper World 3 is a great game if you don't mind playing only single-player, which I think is a tough sell for modern day RTS games (or even tower defense, if you wanna classify it in that bin). It is certainly an interesting concept that works and there is alot of game to be had here, complete with online leaderboards to compete with friends/the world for best level-completion times. While I enjoyed my time in Creeper World 3, I don't think I will  ever get my full moneys worth of fun.The goal is to build and power a multitude of units to combat the creep (akin to the creep in StarCraft). The main mechanic is based off of various geographic levels, or topography, where the creep gradually covers the entire surface of the playing map - or you fight it off and kill it at the source. That is the main enemy.Pros:+Really fresh concept that works well+Tons of replayability and truckloads of units to build and strategies to master+Great value for the price - that is if you don't mind playing a single player RTS for hours on end+It is quite funCons:-Leaderboards are not enough for me-Having a relatively non-mobile enemy for every map can get dull (sometimes the creep has projectiles, etc., but in the end it is pretty much all the same)-Interface needs worth, in example it would have been nice to have mouse-over hotkey help, etc.-Graphics feel datedI can understand why this is one of the top rated RTS games on Steam, but and the end of the day, I need a bit more out of an RTS for any kind of sticking power. I think the enemy needs more complexity.

												If you want it, you've already got it, beat it and got the T-ShirtFor those of you currently unsure of Knuckle Cracker's newest escapade: A resounding 'meh'.I absolutely suck balls at RTS's, not sure why, I just do. While there is some innovation in Arc Eternal (as with all formulaic games like it), it's mostly the same as before, both a blessing and a curse.While the gameplay is fine, it's how it plays that I don't like. Arc Eternal is constant grindfest through the levels, all the same. Get collectors, build turrets, stabilize, then branch out. It's a slow, slow game out there, and that's going to make it or break it for you. While others may relish in it, I can't. Everything is so painfully slow and repetitive, after the initial hour or so of 'Yes! New creeper world!', it became possibly my worst gaming experience, after possibly the end of HL2: Episode 2 and Deus Ex: Human Revolution.For extra salt in the wound, if you overextend by a ♥♥♥♥ing millimeter, the game cuts your ♥♥♥♥ing hand off, your last 30 mins of work explodes in purple creeper, and I almost screamed with rage. For that price tag? No way, just go play one of the free ones online or something.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I could see myself playing a little bit more, but considering the 2 hour limit in order to get a refund, I'll rather stop now. In order to still somehow write a meaningful review I've read a lot about what others had to say (both good and bad) and watched videos online.The problem for me is simple: Every mission is the same basic concept + you are not fighting against any sort of AI, but against some fluid goo which always spreads, you always stop, and then you grind your way forward to destroy it. It's weirdly enjoying and at the same time surprisingly non-engaging. You could play it while watching a film, especially once you have set up base. I can understand how people sink hours into it, just how some people sink hours into mindless point-and-click games, but I see no strategic depth here.Positive Reviews actually acknowledge that to some degree, and the ones talking about any sort of "strategic depth" do a bad job explaining what exactly they mean, while the bad reviews are criticising the same thing, and some of those people have clocked considerably more hours than me.This + looking at videos online has led me to the conclusion that these basic game mechanics don't change, sure there are buildings to unlock, and some tools you have to use in certain situations, but I can't see any possibility of strategic depth with this kind of concept.It would get a good review for 2,49$, maybe for 4,99$ even, I could see myself playing it for a few more hours or sometimes to just waste time, but for 14,99$ I expected more. So get it while on sale, and stop before the 2 hour mark to rethink your investment. It's somewhat enjoyable, but more of a time-waster instead of an engaging game that will make you think.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												This is a gem of a strategy game. It's a RTS Tower defense-esque game, this might not sound like a good idea, but it works beautifully. There are two main mechanics that I will address:1. The Creeper. This is your enemy, it's a liquid entity that creeps forward from spawners, slowly covering more and more of the stage. You need to build towers to fight it back, and in turn advance farther along the stage yourself. Creeper would be very difficult to deal with if it didn't obey the laws of physics. Basically, in order for creeper to overflow onto a higher level of terrain, it has to have nowhere else to go on its current level. This leads to some fairly interesting placements, like a very powerful spawner at the bottom of a deep crater. There are plenty of other enemies too, runners and digitalis namely. Runners just run along digitalis and need to be destroyed with sniper towers, they can't directly destroy your towers, but can stun them long enough for creeper to overflow onto them. Digitalis is a kind of grid-like enemy that conducts creeper and prevents towers from being built, trust me, it's more difficult than it sounds.2. The Network. This game has parallels to a tower defense game, but calling it one doesn't do it justice. The biggest conventional differences being: Towers are networked, they have to be connected to your base to function; Towers can be moved freely, even off the network, albeit with limited ammo; towers use energy, constantly.The biggest difference as I stated is the network. You have to build collectors and relays between towers to provide pathways for the "packets" of which there are three types, ammo, construction, and totem. This means you can't just build towers in the most strategic spots right away, you have to build out to them, often fighting tooth and nail to get to them. Additionally, these packets cost energy, which is distributed evenly between the active types of packets, energy is obtained through collectors, which collect energy across an area, and reactors. Collectors gain no benefit from overlapping area and should be spread out, they are also one of the main staples in your network of towers. If you get too ambitious with your expansion, you'll enter energy starvation, where packets are produced less efficiently and you run the risk of your blasters running out of ammo and the line being pushed back.Between the campaign mode and the hundreds of other levels in the game + fan made ones, you could get hundreds of hours out of this game (I didn't because I just played creeper world 1 and 2 before it and was done after the campaign). Having played all three games, this is the best. Even at full price, I think you'll get your money's worth, this is a difficult game, you will need to think strategically and act quickly. It's a refreshing change of pace from most RTS and tower defense games in my opinion.

												I have personay put hundreds of hours into the three free flash based games, and I loved them all. I saw this game on steam and had to have it. Much to my delight, It has more content than all the previous games, COMBINED. This is a unique kind of tower defense (TD) game, with a much more organic feeling enemy than 'I just follow these paths regardless of the danger to my health.' That single change from the normal TD lets this game have so much more complex and involved levels. The towers range from simple towers like the blaster and mortar, to more complex ones such as the strafer and the XL cannon you get later in the campaign (Called Thors Hammer, if I recall correctly). You also have to manage your infastructure, otherwise your towers will stop working properly, and you WILL die (or at least lose a lot of ground). I love this game, and I hope you can at least give it a try. While this version has no demo, just look up the other Creeper World games online, those should suffice as a propper demo.
