Posted: November 28, 2016
												It is vaguely tower defense...  you cannot control the path of your enemies with your towers, nor does your enemy have a path at all.  Your enemy is "creeper" - an obvious ripoff in name and behavior of Starcraft's creep.  It is goo which expands from a central point.  The goo will destroy your towers so you must keep it at bay.  The whole game is about first protecting your base from the goo then slowly pushing the goo back until you destroy the enemy target.  The graphics are a la 1989.  The gameplay is simplistic.  There is a lot of content, though.  If you are tolerant of poor graphics and this style of game sounds interesting, then it'll keep you occupied for a decent period of time for a low price.  I found it underwhelming, possibly because I like the more traditional tower defense, but I have played it a lot.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												Talk about addictive...Haven't played a "just 5 more minutes" game since Dune II (or Master of Orion II but that was turn based and a completely other kind of game). This game has a lot of resemblance with Dune.Lots of people tag it as tower defense but I don't really agree. For starters, you are the attacker and there really aren't towers. But most of all, tower defense is about repetitiveness, about more and more units attacking in the same way, where this game, also predictable because of its nature with physics, has a much more broad attack style.So what's it about? I'm not really into the story, but it seems some kind of (underground?) monster has some arses in planets and from those asses, it is spreading some kind of liquid. Physics make sure that these fluids flow and spread over your planet, destroying everything that is not planet, wall or enemy on its way. Your weapon against this fluid is some kind of weapon drying it out. Well, not one kind, there are a lot of types and they all have their advantages and disadvantages. It's your job to eradicate these squirters from these world, making sure life can start again on those planets, although some planets have gone too far for this and are only to be cleared of the monster for the technology that is left behind there.This game is terribly addictive. I have played it a lot offline first (bought it through their website to have it DRM free) and activated it with a key on steam.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												CW3:AE is simply amazing and addictive.I remember playing CW1 long ago and loving every bit of it and though CW2 was very different i'm glad they went back to the original style with this one. It's like a mix of TD and RTS, it's like someone looked into the future of Tower Defence and brought it back into the present.Besides the campaign and the surprisingly deep story, you have hundreds of handcrafted maps and thousands of random pre-generated maps(normal and challenging) and a map editor to share your maps with others. Basically, there is enough to play here.In terms of play styles you could go for a speedy/aggresive or tactical approach, but there is an odd satisfaction of systematically taking over the map bit by bit, freeing it from the "Creeper". With the addition of being able to terraform the landscape things get very interesting, going from building your own castles/fortresses to creating artificial chokepoints for the Creeper to simply making the map right out flat as you go along.All in all i would very much recommend getting it on or off sale, but as i said it's quite addictive.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												I saw the word "Creeper" in the name and was curious if some kind of Minecraft ripoff had made its way onto Steam.  What I found was a highly addictive and unique stragegy game.You face the creeper: a flood, literally, a fluid enemy pouring across the battlefield from emitters.  Later encountering corrupted machines and other new threats and rule-bending forces.  Your typical mission begins by dropping your HQ either far enough away or on defensible enough terrain to build up your economy and weapons to begin pushing back.  Branching out your energy network to lands secured by weapons fire (or other interesting units and abilities) to allow units to operate further and further afield, advancing step by step, until close enough to set up a special unit to destroy its source.The games many maps are very diverse.  Fighting on all sorts of mundane and exotic planet surfaces, fragmented worlds, moons, asteroids, vast artificial structures etc.Your economy is energy.  You recieve a constant income of energy from collectors and reactors, which require either plenty of creeper-free land or large investments of energy.  Energy functions as the building material for units and their ammo.  Losing a chunk of your income, or a link in your network of collector and relay nodes, or just spend it on doing too much at once and your weapons will have only several seconds worth of stored energy before that wall of firepower becomes a trickle, or nothing at all.The main con with this game I think is that, with the exception of a few time sensitive missions, you are very unlikely to lose once you have built a decent defense early in the mission.  Once that is accomplished, a player be as slow and patient as they like, lazily inching things forward one at a time as much as terrain allowed.I might have played CW3 that way, and been left with a feeling I wasn't challenged, and that there weren't many important strategic decisions to make... if not for one simple feature: leaderboards for best completion times.  This is one of the few games that have managed to interest me trying to get into the Top-Whatever ammount.  I recommend doing so, it greatly enhances CW3's challenge and replayability.Unfortunately, the leaderboards are polluted with illegitimate scores, particularly in the main campaign and most popular other maps.  I mean times well below what it takes to build, charge and fire a single nullifier even in the best conditions filling the Top 10's and 20's; with legitimate champs finding themselves in around the Top 30's... so at least it's still meaningful to be in the Top 100's.

Posted: May 26, 2016
												This might actually be my favourite RTS(ish?) game.The gameplay is only singleplayer and very much oriented around building a defense grid to resist and overcome a stream of Creeper. The Creeper is a liquid like entity that will accumulate and destroy your buildings if your defense isn't up fast enough.One of the features I think it the coolest about this game is the terrain. Heigh can vary between 1 and 10 and will didctate how the Creeper will flow on the map. It's also possible to terraform it to create things like walls or flatten the place where you want to build.But walls won't help you forever. Creeper isn't limited to the height of 10 and will accumulate untill you destroy all the spawners.That's the basic of it. There is also a few more ennemies and you have about 11 buildings to adapt to each scenario.The main story is cool. The first half will introduce you to new features and the second half will have unique levels to challenge you, especially toward the end. The whole thing is lead by a mysterious sci-fy story.And the best part is that the story is the small part of the game. After the few hours you need to complete it, you have countless more missions to play and also user-created ones.Nice defense RTS, tons of content. It might not be for everyone but check it out!

												Pretty neat game. I first found it as a flash game a few years back, then a while ago I found the flash game again and though, man this would be a cool full game. A quick search on steam revealed that it was!The gameplay of this game is simple, your enemy works exactly like water and will flow out across the landscape dropping into and quickly filling up holes, or build up so much to climb up to higher levels. Your job is to create a defence that blasts back the "creeper" until you can get close enough to destroy the source.With a campaign, different modes, and a user created content section, this game has infinite playability, and I found to be a ton of fun, even though sometimes a single level would take me 3 hours (I like to play really conservatively) I found the game to be a ton of fun, with little to no issues I could find. I would definitely recommend.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												I saw the word "Creeper" in the name and was curious if some kind of Minecraft ripoff had made its way onto Steam.  What I found was a highly addictive and unique stragegy game.You face the creeper: a flood, literally, a fluid enemy pouring across the battlefield from emitters.  Later encountering corrupted machines and other new threats and rule-bending forces.  Your typical mission begins by dropping your HQ either far enough away or on defensible enough terrain to build up your economy and weapons to begin pushing back.  Branching out your energy network to lands secured by weapons fire (or other interesting units and abilities) to allow units to operate further and further afield, advancing step by step, until close enough to set up a special unit to destroy its source.The games many maps are very diverse.  Fighting on all sorts of mundane and exotic planet surfaces, fragmented worlds, moons, asteroids, vast artificial structures etc.Your economy is energy.  You recieve a constant income of energy from collectors and reactors, which require either plenty of creeper-free land or large investments of energy.  Energy functions as the building material for units and their ammo.  Losing a chunk of your income, or a link in your network of collector and relay nodes, or just spend it on doing too much at once and your weapons will have only several seconds worth of stored energy before that wall of firepower becomes a trickle, or nothing at all.The main con with this game I think is that, with the exception of a few time sensitive missions, you are very unlikely to lose once you have built a decent defense early in the mission.  Once that is accomplished, a player be as slow and patient as they like, lazily inching things forward one at a time as much as terrain allowed.I might have played CW3 that way, and been left with a feeling I wasn't challenged, and that there weren't many important strategic decisions to make... if not for one simple feature: leaderboards for best completion times.  This is one of the few games that have managed to interest me trying to get into the Top-Whatever ammount.  I recommend doing so, it greatly enhances CW3's challenge and replayability.Unfortunately, the leaderboards are polluted with illegitimate scores, particularly in the main campaign and most popular other maps.  I mean times well below what it takes to build, charge and fire a single nullifier even in the best conditions filling the Top 10's and 20's; with legitimate champs finding themselves in around the Top 30's... so at least it's still meaningful to be in the Top 100's.

Posted: December 19, 2016
												I just love this game so much, it fills in the gaps and holes other games left in me by being incomplete or bad.Creeper World 3 is a base building tower defense with deep strategy and extra mechanics to keep things interesting. You, the player, Vs. The creeper - A growing, organic, hive fluid that spreads across terrain consumning all in it's path.Cannons, mortars, snipers, big berthas and more!! Are all at your disposal to keep back, and annhilate the creeper and it's tools!!Every mission is different, every map is unique, and there are thousands if not millions of player created maps in addition to the tutorial, campaign, and different sectors. If you enjoy tower defense, a bit of micromanagement, strategy, an adaptive enemy, and so much content that you'll be happy for weeks, hell, even if you enjoy factorio, you'll probably enjoy this game just as much as me. Posted: December 18, 2016
												This is a fun game, a credit to Indie development.  No reason to add to the many positive reviews, except to make a recent one.  The worlds are being covered in alien goo, and it's up to you to drive back that goo.  With a description like that, it could be a dull game, but it isn't.  The game is well crafted.  It isn't gorgeous, but it's good enough.  The gameplay is what it's about anyway.  After each map I have to snap out of a pleasant daze - the game's tempo and sounds keep me completely absorbed in the action.A note about comparison to Particle Fleet: Emergence, by the same developer.  I recommend buying this one first, if you are trying to decide.  CW3 does a better job at explaining the universe that both games take place in, has better writing, is easier to learn the mechanics.  Graphics quality and depth are similar in both.  CW3 focuses on ground combat, PF:E on spaceship combat.  Both are good games, but I had trouble understanding PF:E until I played CW3.  Now I look forward to completing PF:E as well.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												I've been playing this game series for years on flash game websites. This game always manages to entice me to come back to it. It really accomodates a variety of playstyles, from the slow methodical domination strategy, to the clever direct to the goal strategy, from brushing through and taking the point loss to end the map quickly to micromanaging every frame of the game. With the addition of player created maps into the mix it gets even more fun, I've become addicted to the special game modes available in the player created maps specifically one where your role is reversed, this is a great game with simple enough mechanics to learn but the option to find levels that rely on tactics that are hard to master. I would definitely recommend this game to anybody.Just don't up the game speed on larger maps or else you'll actually slow down the game if you don't have the computer for it.

												I dislike these type of pixle games and purchased this game only because of its high rating, despite being burnt for doing the same thing multiple times before.It was a worth while risk and I am still happy with the chance I took with this game.It didn't look much like a 'story' based game but the tale it told was mature, engaging, and well paced.The gameplay would normally be repetative in this type of game however it managed to avoid multiple pitfalls.There is enough challenge where I failed around 40% of missions but never felt frustrated, surprisingly enough.There are a lot of extras after completing the main game which I still play sporadically.I don't think I will ever replay the whole campain again but I would still enjoy it if I did replay it.My personal "Top 10 Hidden Gems of all time"

Posted: February 2
												First off let me tell you that I love this games concept.  the turret deffense along with leaderboards and other things make for a rather interesting game.some key things I have to dissagree with on the concepts.1) leaderboards are broken.  how can you beat a level in less than a min.  it takes more time for your orbitals to land than some of these people took to beat the levels.  I call foul.2) Campaign - It seems choppy at best, and broken as worst.  sure I was able to beat it.  but most of the items you have at your disposal and the fact that even two ore harvesters cannot support one single ore spitter for continuious fire is sad.  then there are the titans.  Useless in ever case.  even on the missions you may want them they take too long to fire, the creep comes back too fast even on 1x speed to do anything tactical with them, and the last one is only for the end mission, you don't even get to use it on special missions after you unlock it.now for the reason that this game is great!1) it has user/mod like interface.  looks to me (haven't finnished all bonus sectors yet) that you get to make and share with other players in these maps.  maybe they just modify/test them first to make sure you don't screw over the comunity, but this is a rather interesting idea.2) the story is actually decent.  Sure it may seem obvious at times, and others down right boring.  However, if you decide to read it all (storyline) you get an interesting story.  one worth talking about to friends and family.  Just like when you read a good book, or new article.3) Replayability - Sure the leaderboards are broken, but you can still post your times and strive to improve them, come up with new and interesting ideas on how to beat the levels, and even strive to limit yourself in ways not ment (like only cannons and solor collectors)In the end this game is worth picking up, yet I would think nothing more than $10 for the short campaign limit, but the extra sectors do make up for the loss in gameplay.  Just wish they had some kind of RPG element sector where you gather things/currency and use them to improve/unlock different items to use in the next mission (like if you could boost yourself with a starting ammount of energy or something)  of course this would destroy the leaderboards in that sector, but that would be something like score rather than just time (like -points per sec and +points for builds and kills.  Also give you a point handycap for bonuses, and a point bonus for detriments)Anyways if you like Tower Defense or base building you may want to check this game out.

												Yes, buy this game.  Resource management, a great enemy, and addictive gameplay.  The bundle is on sale right now for 20% off.  Lots of fun.  As you can see from my stats, it took me about 33 hours to comlete the game.  A great value by any measure.  These guys are macking fun stuff, if you don't know about it, Particle Fleet is lots of fun, too.Spend some of your hard earned cash and support these guys.  They make fun games.  Period.

												This is the King of all Tower Defense games. It is a classic, in a league of it is own. There is nothing else like it. Incredibly addictive, well worth the low cost. If you like tower defense this can entertain you endlessly... Highly recomended to TD and RTS fans.PS: Please make Creeper World 4! I will give you all my money for Creeper World 4!

Posted: January 15
												This is a great game. I like versions 1 and 2 better (version 2 is a completely different game) but this game is great. I wish that they had an in game description of what each unit does like they did in the origional two. It's kinda frustrating to have to leave the game itself to look up the new thing you just unlocked. Could certainly use a better intro to the content.

Posted: January 25
												I first heard about this series by playing the free demos of the first and second one online. I enjoyed them for a long time, and eventually found that this was at the time the only full game on steam. I hadn't bought any of the full games yet so I didn't know the immensity of the game. Although story mode is small but interesting, the rest of the game contains an unfathomable amount of levels, along with the ability to play levels made by yourself and others online. The levels can range from easy or challenging, and this game is more fun if you enjoy having to meticulously fight back agains the opposing creeper and plan your infrastructure. The soundtrack has only 2 songs that play during levels, but they are substantial enought that you will never get tired of them. The story is a little hard to understand because I didn't play the first 2, but the ridiculously large years (evidentally this is trillions of years in the future if not more) make it hard to fathom the amount of time passed, wich is kind of cool.TL:DR Creeper World is a great game that provides countless hours of engaging playtime.

Posted: January 17
												The game is based on a mechanic that invents a completely new "enemy" on the tower defense or RTS genre. The enemy is a liquid that you have to fight back and survive. I love the series and have played through all of the entries. But to be honest, Creeper World 3 was... a disappointment. This one I like the least in the series. I suppose my problem here is lack of innovation. I felt like there was nothing new to the game compared to the old ones. I think I was already waiting for something new but all I got was second base and improved graphics. Even the engine is the same. I feel like I still want to see one more game from the series. But with added content. Not just million maps that in the end, after a few games, are all the same. I want more mechanics, maybe different types of Creeper, more tech, more weapons, maybe upgrades for the weapons, "smart" creeper that activly tries to fight back with different mechanics and weapons and not just flop the predictable way where the game stays hours in a stale mate, and more!I recommend the game but I find the older ones to be more intresting

Posted: February 4
												This game is on my all-time favorites list. I've been heavily, heavily invested in this series since 2009 with the first game, and it got better with every installment. I'd have to say this one is my favorite, def. Playtime is at most a third of my actual playtime since I got this game before it was on steam. The story is so good as the close for the three-game epic through the  entirety of the human race. You really need to play the first two games, esp the initial one, to really appreciate the progression for the protagonist, but the gameplay gives it an excellent stand-alone experience. Bless Knuckle Cracker. Please play this game.

Posted: February 5
												I dislike these type of pixle games and purchased this game only because of its high rating, despite being burnt for doing the same thing multiple times before.It was a worth while risk and I am still happy with the chance I took with this game.It didn't look much like a 'story' based game but the tale it told was mature, engaging, and well paced.The gameplay would normally be repetative in this type of game however it managed to avoid multiple pitfalls.There is enough challenge where I failed around 40% of missions but never felt frustrated, surprisingly enough.There are a lot of extras after completing the main game which I still play sporadically.I don't think I will ever replay the whole campain again but I would still enjoy it if I did replay it.My personal "Top 10 Hidden Gems of all time"

Posted: February 2
												First off let me tell you that I love this games concept.  the turret deffense along with leaderboards and other things make for a rather interesting game.some key things I have to dissagree with on the concepts.1) leaderboards are broken.  how can you beat a level in less than a min.  it takes more time for your orbitals to land than some of these people took to beat the levels.  I call foul.2) Campaign - It seems choppy at best, and broken as worst.  sure I was able to beat it.  but most of the items you have at your disposal and the fact that even two ore harvesters cannot support one single ore spitter for continuious fire is sad.  then there are the titans.  Useless in ever case.  even on the missions you may want them they take too long to fire, the creep comes back too fast even on 1x speed to do anything tactical with them, and the last one is only for the end mission, you don't even get to use it on special missions after you unlock it.now for the reason that this game is great!1) it has user/mod like interface.  looks to me (haven't finnished all bonus sectors yet) that you get to make and share with other players in these maps.  maybe they just modify/test them first to make sure you don't screw over the comunity, but this is a rather interesting idea.2) the story is actually decent.  Sure it may seem obvious at times, and others down right boring.  However, if you decide to read it all (storyline) you get an interesting story.  one worth talking about to friends and family.  Just like when you read a good book, or new article.3) Replayability - Sure the leaderboards are broken, but you can still post your times and strive to improve them, come up with new and interesting ideas on how to beat the levels, and even strive to limit yourself in ways not ment (like only cannons and solor collectors)In the end this game is worth picking up, yet I would think nothing more than $10 for the short campaign limit, but the extra sectors do make up for the loss in gameplay.  Just wish they had some kind of RPG element sector where you gather things/currency and use them to improve/unlock different items to use in the next mission (like if you could boost yourself with a starting ammount of energy or something)  of course this would destroy the leaderboards in that sector, but that would be something like score rather than just time (like -points per sec and +points for builds and kills.  Also give you a point handycap for bonuses, and a point bonus for detriments)Anyways if you like Tower Defense or base building you may want to check this game out.

Posted: February 15
												An excellent game with nicely paced progression.You'll rage during some levels but once you complete it you'll realize it wasn't hard at all.The game forces you to try new strategies and use all your capabilites - no one approach beats all levels.Recommended.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Pros:A unique blend of RTS and Tower Defense is an innovative twist on a tired genre.  Seriously.  I'm utterly shocked nobody else has stolen this and applied their own game to it yet.Maps vary wildly in difficulty, taxing your ability no matter how experienced you are at the game.Cons:*If you have a technical issue, the developer's response will be "It works for everyone else, it must be a problem on your end.  Good luck fixing it.*  If you buy this game, try it immediately to make sure everything's kosher, so you can return it if it something doesn't pan out.Story is short and painfully one-dimensional.Balancing issues abound.  Since the enemy never gets any stronger, and you never stop getting stronger, surviving the first few minutes is tantamount to winning the map; Clearing emitters is a formality.Some maps are 100% objectively impossible to beat.Certain achievements aren't so much "achievements" as "medals for playing a really really long time."--That said, the game is worth playing for no other reason than to experience the unique gameplay.

content:
Posted: March 31
												Amazing strategic tower defense but utterly unique with its grey-goo style enemy. Evokes the AI gone wrong scenario that you struggle against. Each level, trying to establish a bulkhead before you're taken over. Usually once stabilized you can push forward without fear of being overrun but still racing against the clock and any surprises in store. Haven't really got immersed in other TDs with enemies that span periodically to march single-file down an alley of death - such non-strategic thinking (no timed runs or efforts to undermine the offense battery) that it breaks my suspenion-of-disbelief. On the other hand, the premise in this game does feel plausible.

Posted: April 24
												Tags : Casual - Puzzle - VisualAdditional Tags : Tower DefenseCreeper World 3 is a connect the dot puzzle/tower defense hybrid with a thin sci fi post apoc plot.Different dots have different specialties and pipeline ammo to your guns from your HQ/Engine. Your goal is to shoot at basically a water spill to prevent it from spilling then plug the source by rolling it back carefullyThey went through the hassle of remaking it in unity. I played a couple matches, its not great by any means but it does accomplish what it set out to do and does provide a fair distraction but can only be enjoyed in short bursts before it gets really boringIt is debatable if this game is any better than a flash game offering. My guess is not but I will play more to test it out

Posted: April 16
												This is a neat game, lots of fun.The steam achievements are awful. Enormous waste of time - tons of grind/repetition. Otherwise I'd give it a thumbs up - if you don't care about achievements, give it a go. If you're a completionist / 100%er, avoid it!

Posted: April 21
												The slow and steady creep of your eventual demise is highly compelling. Will you solidify your defenses first and eventually overwhelm the creep with superior economy? Or will you blitzkrieg the closest emmiter to gain an early advantage? Balanced, well polished, and simple to understand mechanics combined with creative maps, both from the developer and community, make for high replayability and creativity.Easily my favorite tower defense since the days of Warcraft 3.
